response:
[start of motion plan]
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

Mapping World Motion to Wrist Motion:
The provided workspace image confirms that the scene involves a human arm resting on a table, with the robot end-effector grasping the wrist near the hand. The environment includes a flat, horizontal surface (table) and background workspace with various objects. The human wrist is currently dislocated, suggested by the positioning of the hand and wrist relative to the forearm; the task is to reposition the wrist joint correctly by applying controlled motions.

The labeled wrist axes correspond to the world as such: The wrist frame's X-axis (red) points roughly towards the right side of the image (world +X), Y-axis (green) points roughly forward into the scene (world +Z direction), and Z-axis (blue) points upward in the image (world +Y). This orientation aligns the wrist axes with the robot gripper frame and allow motions in the wrist frame to correspond sensibly with the world directions noted.

The blue axis represents wrist Z-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to vertical motion upward (+Z wrist) being upward in the image and world vertical (world +Y). Negative motion is downward. 

Based on knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Z-axis, the wrist must move positively (upward) to realign the joint, lifting the wrist slightly off the surface to disengage the dislocation and move it back into place.

The red axis represents wrist X-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to lateral lateral side-to-side motion rightwards in the image/world (+X). 

Based on knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist X-axis, the wrist must move slightly negatively (leftward) to align the distal part of the wrist relative to the forearm.

The green axis represents wrist Y-axis motion. It roughly corresponds to forward and backward motion into and out of the image (world +Z).

Based on knowledge of the task and motion, in the wrist Y-axis, the wrist must move slightly positively (further into the scene) to help close the joint socket and reset the wrist.

To accomplish the task in the wrist frame, the object must be moved primarily upward (+Z wrist), with small corrective lateral (-X wrist) and forward (+Y wrist) components to gently reposition the wrist into anatomical alignment.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist, we consider:

- Object Properties: The human wrist and forearm have a combined mass of approximately 2 kg for the distal arm section. The wrist bones and soft tissue exhibit flexibility and some resistance through muscle and ligament tension. Friction between skin and robot gripper is moderate. The wrist joint is articulated with resistance but can be gently manipulated.

- Environmental Factors: The arm rests on a rigid flat table (wood or composite) with a moderate friction coefficient (~0.5) against skin and clothing. Gravity acts downward perpendicular to table. Manipulation requires lifting the wrist slightly off the surface to realign without excessive force to avoid injury.

- The relevant object is the human wrist and hand with soft tissue and bones, having mass roughly 2 kg and with the robot gripper, a static friction coefficient of about 0.7 to securely hold without slipping.

- The surface of interaction is the wooden table with a static friction coefficient of about 0.5 against the arm.

- Contact Types: The robot maintains a firm pinch grasp around the wrist, ensuring stable contact on multiple sides to enable safe force transmission.

- Motion Type: The motion involves lifting (linear positive Z), medial translation (linear negative X), slight forward translation (linear positive Y), and controlled wrist rotation (torques) to reset the dislocation.

- Contact Considerations: Forces along X and Y must be combined with grip force to maintain contact without slipping; Z force must overcome gravity and joint resilience; torques must be applied smoothly to manipulate joint alignment without causing pain.

- Motion along axes: The robot exerts combined linear motions in X, Y, and Z axes plus small angular corrections about Y (pitch) and possibly X (roll) to rotate and reposition wrist bones.

- Task duration: The repositioning should be done carefully within approximately 5 seconds to allow controlled manipulation.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: mass ~2 kg, gravity force ~ 19.6 N, friction coefficients 0.7 (gripper-wrist), 0.5 (table-arm).

- Relevant equations: Required force to overcome friction = friction coefficient * normal force; torque to overcome joint resistance estimated roughly at 1-2 N-m based on typical wrist torque capabilities.

- Relevant assumptions: The wrist is moderately dislocated with some resistance but no blockage forcing large force; the robot gripper does not slip with 10-15 N applied grasp force.

- Computations: Lifting the wrist off table requires the robot to exert slightly more than 19.6 N in Z plus some margin for acceleration and joint resistance (~25 N). Translation along X and Y requires lower forces to reposition; assume ~5 N for mild lateral and forward forces. Torque about Y axis (pitch) of about 1 N-m will suffice to rotate wrist into place.

- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 2 kg and static friction coefficient 0.7 along the surface: Overcome gravity: 2 kg * 9.8 m/s² = 19.6 N in Z direction; frictional forces manageable with given grip force.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon the required lateral adjustment and friction, the object in the image must exert negative force (leftward) along the X-axis with magnitude 5 N.

Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon the forward translation and friction, the object in the image must exert positive force (forward) along the Y-axis with magnitude 5 N.

Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon overcoming gravity and lifting the wrist, the object in the image must exert positive force (upward) along the Z-axis with magnitude 25 N.

Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon wrist joint manipulation needs, the object in the image must exert clockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 0.5 N-m (small roll correction).

Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon required rotation to realign the wrist joint, the object in the image must exert counterclockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 1.0 N-m (primary pitch correction).

Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon task requirements, no torque is required about the Z-axis.

Grasping force: Estimated gripping force to securely hold wrist with skin contact friction 0.7 and arm mass 2 kg is 10 to 15 N, sufficient to prevent slip while allowing gentle manipulation.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Human wrist and hand with soft tissue and bones, approx. 2 kg mass, skin-gripper friction coefficient ~0.7, resting on wooden table with 0.5 friction coefficient."

# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Lift wrist upward (+Z), slight leftward translation (-X), slight forward translation (+Y), with gentle clockwise roll torque and counterclockwise pitch torque to realign joint."

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of motion across the wrist axes [x, y ,z]. 
wrist_motion_vector = [-0.02, 0.02, 0.05]  # meters: 2 cm left, 2 cm forward, 5 cm up

# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [-5, 5, 25, -0.5, 1.0, 0]  # Forces in N, torques in N-m

# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 12  # N, within estimated range

# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 5.0  # seconds for careful manipulation
```
[end of motion plan]

Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to set the dislocated wrist back in place while grasping the wrist.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
